docs.title: Apify
docs.text: Make everything as API - A flexible, high-performance API framework that automatically generates CRUD operations from OpenAPI specifications.

docs.title: 🚀 Quick Start
docs.text:
The fastest way to get Apify running is using our quickstart script:

curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/apifyhost/apify/main/quickstart.sh | bash

This will: 1. Download the necessary files 2. Start Apify with a sample configuration 3. Provide you with access URLs

For more details, see the Quick Start Guide.

docs.title: 🚀 Zero-Code CRUD
docs.text: Define your data models in OpenAPI specs with x-table-schemas, and Apify automatically generates complete CRUD endpoints (Create, Read, Update, Delete) with database operations.

docs.title: 🗄️ Multi-Database Support
docs.text: Support for SQLite and PostgreSQL backends with automatic connection pooling and schema initialization.

docs.title: 🔐 Built-in Security
docs.text:
• API Key authentication
  • OAuth 2.0 / OIDC support
  • Automatic Audit Trail for tracking changes
  • Granular access control

docs.title: ⚡ High Performance
docs.text: Built on Rust and Tokio, featuring multi-threaded architecture and zero-copy request routing.

docs.title: 📚 Documentation
docs.text:
Full documentation is available at https://apifyhost.github.io/apify/.

  • Getting Started

docs.title: Control Plane API
docs.text: The Control Plane API allows you to manage the Apify instance programmatically.

docs.title: Health Check
docs.text: GET /health Returns the health status of the service.

docs.title: Reload Configuration
docs.text: POST /_/reload Triggers a hot reload of the configuration files without restarting the server.

docs.title: Metrics
docs.text: GET /metrics Exposes Prometheus metrics (if enabled).

docs.title: OpenAPI Documentation
docs.text:
If the openapi_docs module is enabled (default port 4001):

  • GET /docs: Swagger UI interface.
  • GET /openapi.json: Aggregated OpenAPI 3.0 specification for all configured APIs.

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
If control_plane.admin_key is configured in config.yaml, all requests to the Control Plane API (typically under /apify/admin/) must include the authentication header:

X-API-KEY: <your-admin-key>

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text: Apify is built on a modular, high-performance architecture designed for scalability and flexibility.

docs.title: Control Plane (CP)
docs.text:
• Manages configuration, APIs, and datasources
  • Provides REST API for dynamic updates
  • Stores metadata in a dedicated database
  • Pushes updates to Data Plane without restarts

docs.title: Data Plane (DP)
docs.text:
• Handles actual API traffic
  • Executes CRUD operations
  • Manages database connections
  • Enforces authentication and authorization

docs.title: Request Lifecycle
docs.text:
1. HeaderParse: Extract and validate HTTP headers
  2. BodyParse: Parse and validate request body
  3. Route: Match request to API operation
  4. Access: Authentication and authorization
  5. Data: Execute CRUD operations
  6. Response: Format and return response
  7. Log: Request and response logging

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
• Multi-threaded: Uses SO_REUSEPORT for efficient connection handling
  • Async I/O: Built on Tokio runtime
  • Zero-Copy: Optimized request routing

docs.title: Control Plane
docs.text: The Control Plane (CP) is responsible for managing the configuration of the Apify instance. It provides a REST API to dynamically add, update, or remove APIs and datasources without restarting the server.

docs.title: Import API
docs.text:
Endpoint: POST /apify/admin/apis

Import a single OpenAPI specification.

curl -X POST http://127.0.0.1:4000/apify/admin/apis \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "name": "demo-api",
    "version": "1.0.0",
    "spec": { ... }
  }'

docs.title: Bulk Import
docs.text:
Endpoint: POST /apify/admin/import

Import a complete configuration file.

curl -X POST http://127.0.0.1:4000/apify/admin/import \
  --data-binary @config.yaml

docs.title: Data Plane
docs.text: The Data Plane is the high-performance engine responsible for handling actual API traffic. It executes the logic defined by the Control Plane configuration.

docs.title: Responsibilities
docs.text:
1. Request Handling: Accepts incoming HTTP requests on configured ports.
  2. Routing: Matches requests to specific API endpoints defined in OpenAPI specs.
  3. Validation: Validates request parameters and bodies against the OpenAPI schema.
  4. Execution:
    • SQL Generation: Converts API requests into optimized SQL queries.
    • Database Interaction: Executes queries against the configured data sources.
  5. Response Formatting: Formats database results into JSON responses matching the schema.

docs.title: Performance
docs.text: The Data Plane is built in Rust for maximum performance and low latency. It uses asynchronous I/O and connection pooling to handle high concurrency.

docs.title: Request Lifecycle
docs.text: Understanding how a request flows through Apify.

docs.title: Flow
docs.text:
1. Ingress: Request arrives at a configured Listener (e.g., port 8080).
  2. Routing: The router matches the URL path and HTTP method to an Operation defined in an OpenAPI spec.
  3. Authentication:
    • Global auth providers check for credentials (e.g., API Key).
    • If valid, the request proceeds.
  4. Validation:
    • Path parameters, query parameters, and request body are validated against the OpenAPI schema.
    • Invalid requests are rejected with 400 Bad Request.
  5. Processing:
    • The x-apify-action determines the logic (e.g., list, create).
    • SQL is generated based on the action and parameters.
  6. Data Access:
    • The query is executed against the mapped Datasource.
  7. Response:
    • Results are serialized to JSON.
    • Response headers are set.
    • Response is sent to the client.

docs.title: API Definition (OpenAPI)
docs.text: Apify uses standard OpenAPI 3.0 files to define APIs. These files can be in YAML or JSON format. Apify extends the OpenAPI specification with custom extensions to define the underlying database schema and link API operations to database actions.

docs.title: Table Schema Definition (x-table-schemas)
docs.text:
You can define the database tables that back your API using the x-table-schemas extension at the root of your OpenAPI document. This configuration allows Apify to automatically create or migrate tables in the configured Datasource.

Note: All property names in these extensions use camelCase.

openapi: 3.0.0
info:
  title: Users API
  version: 1.0.0
x-table-schemas:
  - tableName: "users"
    columns:
      - name: "id"
        columnType: "INTEGER"
        primaryKey: true
        autoIncrement: true
        nullable: false
      - name: "email"
        columnType: "TEXT"
        unique: true
        nullable: false
      - name: "name"
        columnType: "TEXT"
        nullable: true
    indexes: []

docs.title: Table Schema Properties
docs.text: Property Type Description tableName String The name of the table in the database. columns Array List of column definitions. indexes Array (Optional) List of indexes. relations Array (Optional) List of relations (e.g. nested objects).

docs.title: Column Properties
docs.text: Property Type Default Description name String Required Column name. columnType String Required Database type (e.g., INTEGER, TEXT, VARCHAR(255), BOOLEAN). The specific types depend on the underlying driver (SQLite/Postgres). nullable Boolean false Whether the column allows NULL values. primaryKey Boolean false Whether this is a primary key. unique Boolean false Whether values must be unique. autoIncrement Boolean false Whether the DB automatically increments this value. defaultValue String null Default value for the column.

docs.title: Linking Operations to Tables
docs.text:
Apify binds standard HTTP methods to CRUD operations.

  • GET /collection -> List
  • POST /collection -> Create
  • GET /collection/{id} -> Get One
  • PUT /collection/{id} -> Update
  • DELETE /collection/{id} -> Delete

Apify automatically tries to infer the target table for a CRUD operation based on the path. You can explicitly define the target table using x-table-name at the operation level if automatic inference fails or if you want to map a path to a different table.

paths:
  /users:
    get:
      operationId: listUsers
      x-table-name: "users"
      responses:
        '200':
          description: List of users

docs.title: Enabling Modules (x-modules)
docs.text:
You can enable specific Apify modules for an endpoint using the x-modules extension. This is commonly used for authentication or applying specific middleware.

paths:
  /secure-data:
    get:
      x-modules:
        access: ["key_auth"]
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Secure data
Key Value Description access Array of Strings List of auth/access modules to enable (e.g., key_auth).

docs.title: Main Configuration
docs.text: The main configuration file (config.yaml) controls the global settings of the Apify instance.

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
# Global datasource configuration
datasource:
  sqlite1:
    driver: sqlite
    database: ./apify.sqlite
    max_pool_size: 5

# Global consumer (API key) configuration
auth:
  - name: default-api-keys
    type: api-key
    enabled: true
    config:
      source: header
      key_name: X-API-KEY
      consumers:
        - name: default
          keys:
            - dev-key-123

# Control Plane configuration
control-plane:
  listen:
    ip: 0.0.0.0
    port: 3001
  database:
    driver: sqlite
    database: ./cp.sqlite
  auth_token: "my-secret-token"

# HTTP listeners
listeners:
  - name: public
    port: 3000
    ip: 0.0.0.0
    protocol: HTTP

# Global API definitions (mapping APIs to Listeners)
apis:
  - path: openapi/users.yaml
    listeners: 
      - public
    datasource: sqlite1

docs.title: Datasource
docs.text: Defines database connections available to APIs.

docs.title: Auth
docs.text: Configures global authentication providers.

docs.title: Listeners
docs.text: Configures HTTP servers. Note that each listener must have a unique name to be referenced by APIs.

docs.title: Apis
docs.text: Defines which OpenAPI specifications to load and which listeners they should be attached to. * path: Path to the OpenAPI file. * listeners: List of listener names that will serve this API. * datasource: The default datasource to use for operations in this API.

docs.title: Control Plane
docs.text:
Configures the Management API server.

  • listen: Binding address and port.
  • database: Metadata storage database (typically SQLite).
  • admin_key: (Optional) If set, requires X-API-KEY: <key> header for all /apify/admin endpoints.

docs.title: Modules
docs.text:
You can enable additional, system-wide modules in the main configuration.

modules:
  openapi_docs:
    enabled: true
    port: 4001
  metrics:
    enabled: true
    port: 9090

docs.title: OpenAPI Documentation Server (openapi_docs)
docs.text:
The openapi_docs module serves the aggregated OpenAPI specification and a Swagger UI to visualize it.

  • enabled: (Boolean) Enable/Disable the docs server.
  • port: (Integer) The port where the Docs Server will listen.

Once enabled, you can access: * Swagger UI: http://localhost:<port>/docs (e.g., http://localhost:4001/docs) * Combined OpenAPI Spec: http://localhost:<port>/openapi.json

docs.title: Audit Trail
docs.text: The audit trail feature automatically tracks who created and last modified database records when users are authenticated via OAuth/OIDC.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text: When you mark fields as readOnly in your OpenAPI schema, Apify automatically: 1. Creates the corresponding database columns 2. Injects user identity on CREATE operations (for createdBy and updatedBy) 3. Injects user identity on UPDATE operations (for updatedBy only) 4. Prevents users from overriding these values

docs.title: Supported Audit Fields
docs.text:
• createdBy (TEXT): User ID who created the record
  • updatedBy (TEXT): User ID who last updated the record
  • createdAt (DATETIME): Timestamp when created (auto-populated by database)
  • updatedAt (DATETIME): Timestamp when last updated

docs.title: Method 1: Using OpenAPI Schema (Recommended)
docs.text:
Define your schema in components.schemas with readOnly fields:

openapi:
  spec:
    openapi: 3.0.0
    components:
      schemas:
        Task:
          type: object
          required:
            - title
          properties:
            id:
              type: integer
              readOnly: true
            title:
              type: string
            createdBy:
              type: string
              readOnly: true
              description: User who created the task
            updatedBy:
              type: string
              readOnly: true
              description: User who last updated the task
            createdAt:
              type: string
              format: date-time
              readOnly: true
            updatedAt:
              type: string
              format: date-time
              readOnly: true

docs.title: Method 2: Using x-table-schemas
docs.text:
Directly define table columns with auto_field: true:

openapi:
  spec:
    x-table-schemas:
      - table_name: "items"
        columns:
          - name: "createdBy"
            column_type: "TEXT"
            nullable: true
            auto_field: true
          - name: "updatedBy"
            column_type: "TEXT"
            nullable: true
            auto_field: true
          - name: "createdAt"
            column_type: "DATETIME"
            nullable: true
            default_value: "CURRENT_TIMESTAMP"
            auto_field: true
          - name: "updatedAt"
            column_type: "DATETIME"
            nullable: true
            auto_field: true

docs.title: Authentication & Authorization
docs.text: Apify provides built-in support for multiple authentication methods.

docs.title: Supported Methods
docs.text:
• API Key: Simple header-based authentication.
  • OAuth 2.0 / OIDC: Integration with identity providers like Keycloak, Auth0, etc.

docs.title: API Key Authentication
docs.text:
Configure via components.securitySchemes in your OpenAPI spec.

components:
  securitySchemes:
    ApiKeyAuth:
      type: apiKey
      in: header
      name: X-API-KEY
security:
  - ApiKeyAuth: []

docs.title: OAuth 2.0 / OIDC
docs.text: Supports: - Token introspection - JWT validation - Automatic JWKS caching - Issuer and audience validation

docs.title: Access Control
docs.text: Access control can be configured at multiple levels: - Operation Level: Per API endpoint. - Route Level: Per URL path. - Listener Level: Per network port.

docs.title: Relations and Nested Objects
docs.text: Apify supports creating related records in a single API request using nested objects. This feature is inspired by modern ORM practices and makes it easy to work with related data without multiple API calls.

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
# Create an order with multiple items in ONE request
curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/orders \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "customer_name": "Alice",
    "total": 150.00,
    "items": [
      {"product_name": "Laptop", "quantity": 1, "price": 100.00},
      {"product_name": "Mouse", "quantity": 2, "price": 25.00}
    ]
  }'

docs.title: Define Relations in OpenAPI Schema
docs.text:
Use the x-relation extension to define relationships:

components:
  schemas:
    Order:
      type: object
      properties:
        customer_name:
          type: string
        items:
          type: array
          x-relation:                # ← Relation definition
            type: hasMany            # Relation type
            target: OrderItem        # Target schema name
            foreignKey: order_id     # Foreign key in child table
            localKey: id             # Optional: local key (defaults to "id")
          items:
            $ref: '#/components/schemas/OrderItem'

    OrderItem:
      type: object
      properties:
        order_id:
          type: integer
          description: Foreign key to orders
        product_name:
          type: string
        quantity:
          type: integer
        price:
          type: number

docs.title: hasMany (One-to-Many)
docs.text:
Use case: A parent record has multiple child records

Example: Order has many OrderItems

Order:
  properties:
    items:
      type: array
      x-relation:
        type: hasMany
        target: OrderItem
        foreignKey: order_id

docs.title: hasOne (One-to-One)
docs.text:
Use case: A parent record has a single related record

Example: User has one Profile

User:
  properties:
    profile:
      type: object
      x-relation:
        type: hasOne
        target: Profile
        foreignKey: user_id

docs.title: belongsTo (Many-to-One)
docs.text:
Use case: A child record references a parent record

Example: OrderItem belongs to Product

OrderItem:
  properties:
    product:
      type: object
      x-relation:
        type: belongsTo
        target: Product
        foreignKey: product_id

docs.title: Zero-Code CRUD Operations
docs.text: Define your data models in OpenAPI specs with x-table-schemas, and Apify automatically generates complete CRUD endpoints (Create, Read, Update, Delete) with database operations. No boilerplate code needed!

docs.title: How it works
docs.text:
1. Define Schema: Add x-table-schemas to your OpenAPI spec.
  2. Auto-Generation: Apify parses the spec and generates SQL queries.
  3. Execution: Requests are routed to the generated handlers.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
openapi: 3.0.0
info:
  title: Users API
  version: 1.0.0
paths:
  /users:
    get:
      summary: List users
      responses:
        '200':
          description: OK
    post:
      summary: Create user
      responses:
        '201':
          description: Created
components:
  schemas:
    User:
      type: object
      properties:
        id:
          type: integer
        name:
          type: string
x-table-schemas:
  users:
    columns:
      - name: id
        type: integer
        primary_key: true
        auto_increment: true
      - name: name
        type: string

docs.title: Docker Deployment Guide
docs.text: This guide explains how to build and deploy Apify using Docker.

docs.title: Using Docker Compose (Recommended)
docs.text:
Run with SQLite: 

docker compose up apify-sqlite

Run with PostgreSQL (Split Control Plane and Data Plane): 

docker compose up postgres apify-cp apify-dp

docs.title: Using Docker CLI
docs.text:
Build the image: 

docker build -t apify:latest .

Run with SQLite: 

docker run -d \
  --name apify \
  -p 3000:3000 \
  -v $(pwd)/apify/config:/app/config:ro \
  -v apify-data:/app/data \
  apify:latest

Run with PostgreSQL: 

docker run -d \
  --name apify \
  -p 3000:3000 \
  -v $(pwd)/apify/config:/app/config:ro \
  -e POSTGRES_HOST=your-postgres-host \
  apify:latest

docs.title: Control Plane and Data Plane Separation
docs.text:
You can run Control Plane and Data Plane as separate services for better scalability and security.

# Run Control Plane
docker run -d \
  --name apify-cp \
  -p 4000:4000 \
  -v $(pwd)/config:/app/config:ro \
  -v apify-metadata:/app/data \
  apify:latest \
  apify --control-plane -c /app/config/config.yaml

# Run Data Plane
docker run -d \
  --name apify-dp \
  -p 3000:3000 \
  -v $(pwd)/config:/app/config:ro \
  -v apify-metadata:/app/data \
  apify:latest \
  apify --data-plane -c /app/config/config.yaml

docs.title: Image Details
docs.text:
• Base Image: Ubuntu 24.04 (minimal)
  • Size: ~150MB (optimized multi-stage build)
  • Platforms: linux/amd64, linux/arm64 (for releases)
  • User: Runs as non-root user apify (UID 1000)

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
• RUST_LOG - Set log level (error, warn, info, debug, trace)
  • APIFY_THREADS - Number of worker threads (default: 2)

docs.title: Volumes
docs.text:
• /app/config - Configuration files (mount your config directory here)
  • /app/data - Data directory for SQLite databases

docs.title: Health Check
docs.text:
The container includes a health check that runs every 30 seconds: 

docker inspect --format='{{.State.Health.Status}}' apify

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Rust 1.70 or higher (for building from source)
  • Docker (recommended for quick start)
  • SQLite (included) or PostgreSQL server

docs.title: From Source
docs.text:
1. Clone the repository 

    git clone https://github.com/apifyhost/apify.git
cd apify

  2. Build the project 

    cargo build --release --package apify

  3. Run the binary 

    ./target/release/apify -c config.yaml

docs.title: Recommended Method
docs.text:
The fastest way to get Apify running is using the quickstart script:

# Download and run the quickstart script
curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/apifyhost/apify/main/quickstart.sh | bash

The quickstart script will: - ✅ Download and extract all necessary files - ✅ Pull the Docker image - ✅ Start Apify with SQLite - ✅ Display access URLs and quick commands

docs.title: Quickstart Commands
docs.text:
./quickstart.sh install   # Download and install (default)
./quickstart.sh start     # Start services
./quickstart.sh stop      # Stop services
./quickstart.sh status    # Check service status
./quickstart.sh destroy   # Remove installation

docs.title: Manual Docker Setup
docs.text:
If you prefer to run Docker manually:

# Pull the latest image
docker pull apifyhost/apify:latest

# Run with SQLite
docker run -d \
  -p 3000:3000 \
  -v $(pwd)/config:/app/config:ro \
  -v apify-data:/app/data \
  apifyhost/apify:latest

For more details, see the Docker Guide.
